INTRODUCTION HE subject of this paper is filtering and control T for sampled-data systems. Consider a continuous-time linear time-invariant plant and suppose we are given only sampled output measurements at discrete instants of time.

We investigate the problem of designing controllers/filters for the continuous-time plant that satisfy given performance requirements. The &", performance requirements are defined directly in terms of the continuous-time signals and thus take intersample behavior into account. For example, in the filtering problem, the filter is required to produce a continuous-time estimate of a given linear function of the continuous-time system state and the resulting system is required satisfy a given bound on the induced norm of the operator mapping the continuous-time process noise and the discrete-time measurement noise to the continuous-time filtering error. Similarly, in the control problem, the controller is required to provide a given level of attenuation on the effect of the continuous-time exogenous disturbance signals and the discrete-time measurement noise on the continuous-time controlled outputs. These problems are motivated by a need to develop a theory of digital control that deals with intersample behavior explicitly.

This work is related to the recent work in control of sampled-data systems as well as state-space Xm control theory. A number of papers have appeared recently that deal with robust and optimal control of sampled-data systems. (See the recent survey paper by Francis [9] which Bemhard [3], Bemhard 141, Chen and Francis [71, Hara and Kabamba [lo], Tadmor [26], and Toivonen [27]. However, there is one major difference between our work and all of these papers with the notable exceptioys [21, [41, [26]: in most of these papers, it is assumed that the controller is a discrete-time linear time-invariant system with a given and fixed, most often a zero order, hold function. We do not make this assumption. The only assumption is that the filter/controller is a causal system. This has some interesting consequences that will be discussed later in this Introduction.

Taking a state-space approach, we give solutions to a number of x filtering and control problems. In each case, we give necessary and sufficient condition for the existence of a causal filter/controller satisfying a specified

x performance requirement. These necessary and sufficient conditions are in terms of the existence of solutions to matrix (algebraic or differential) Riccati equations. If these solutions exist, then we give formulae for filters/controllers that satisfy the given Z m performance requirement. Our approach draws upon the previous work in state-space &", filtering and control theory [2], [41, [81, [131-[161, [19], [22], [251, [281, [29] and the references cited there. Our results generalize the results of Bemhard [41,BaSar and Bemhard [3] who have obtained similar results in the finite horizon case by using a game-theoretic approach. Tadmor [26] has also obtained some results which are somewhat related to our results. Our solutions to the &", control/filtering problem for easily computed by solving two (one) algebraic Riccati equations which are given directly in terms of the problem data. The generalized hold function depends on the system matrices as well as the % performance bound. Thus, once the &", performance bound y is fixed (as close to the optimal performance as desired), one can assume that the controller is a discrete-time linear time-invariant system followed by the hold function as given by our results without loss of generality. Thus, in this specific sense, the hold function is y suboptimal. This is in contrast to the most of the existing work on x control of sampled-data systems where the hold function is kept fixed and the controller is assumed to be a discrete-time linear timeinvariant system. There is another major difference between our results and those in [l], [lo], and [27]. In [l], [lo], and [271 the sampled-data control problem is solved by transforming the problem into an equivalent discrete-time &", con- troller design problem for a suitably constructed discretetime plant. By contrast, our solution is given directly in terms of the given continuous-time plant data. Indeed, the matrix Riccati equations are given explicitly in terms of the plant system matrices and no transformations are needed. Moreover, the Riccati equations are related in a very natural way to the solution in the standard continuous-time case [81.

While we have formulated these results in the context of Z control, they have immediate applications in robust control of sampled-data systems. Using the recent results on robust stability analysis of sampled-data systems [21], one can use these results for robust stabilization of linear continuous-time systems with norm bounded unstructured uncertainty.

The organization of the paper is as follows: in the next section, we will introduce some elementary properties of linear systems with jumps. These may be regarded as a general framework for dealing with hybrid systems, although we will not focus on this aspect in this paper. We will present results on filtering problems in Section 111, control problems in Section IV. The remainder of the paper will be devoted to the proofs. This organization should optimize the readability of the paper.

The results of this paper were presented at the 1991 International Symposium on the Mathematical Theory of Networks and Systems and the 1991 American Control Conference. A brief conference version of this paper has appeared in 1241.

In between the sampling instants, the state estimate evolves according to the plant dynamics (with w = 0). At the sampling instants, the measurement y(ih) is used to update the estimate. The Z control problem we address in this paper is that of designing a causal controller 3 which uses the sampled measurements y(ih) and reduces the worst case effect of the exogenous signals w, U on the regulated outputs z. To be precise, a controller is a system which takes the sampled output measurements and generates a continuoustime control input signal U. Similarly, a controller 3 is said to be causal if its output only depends on current and past inputs.

The controller 3 will be required to internally stabilize the system G. Internal stability can be defined in several different ways. For our purposes, it can be taken to mean that for any initial state of the system G, all resulting signals are norm bounded. As a matter of fact, the controllers that we will give yield internal exponential stability in a state-space sense.

The rest is similar to the proof above. U VII. CONCLUSIONS In this paper, we have solved certain &", filtering and control problems for systems with sampled measurements. Our solutions are given in terms of Riccati algebraic/differential equations (with jumps). We do not assume that the control is applied through a zero order or a given hold. In fact, our result generates the "optimal" hold function(s) from the problem data. The controllers can be computed by solving one continuous-time and one discrete-time algebraic Riccati equation. Our solution also shares many qualitative properties with the standard X solution. For example, the controller has the structure of an &", estimator for the full information control law in the presence of the worst disturbance. Indeed, the technical novelty lies in the filtering problem since the fullinformation control law does not depend on the sampled-data nature of the problem.
